Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AToL: PorToL - The Porifera Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
A grant has been awarded to the University of Alabama at Birmingham under the direction of Dr. Robert W. Thacker for assembling the phylogenetic tree of sponges. Sponges are an ancient animal group with simple body construction. They are extremely efficient at filtering bacteria and other small food particles from the water in which they live, with thousands of different sponge species found in the world's oceans and freshwater habitats. Along with their important ecological roles, sponges can yield potential new medicines and host an extraordinary diversity of microbial life. Despite their widespread presence in aquatic habitats, the study of sponges has lagged behind that of other more charismatic marine fauna. Sponges pose special difficulties for those interested in deciphering their taxonomy, classification, and evolutionary relationships because sponge bodies are quite plastic, varying from one individual to the next. These difficulties hamper progress in basic studies of sponge biology and biodiversity, including comparative studies aimed at understanding the evolution of animals and efforts to conserve or economically exploit aquatic ecosystems. Using molecular genetic data from 8,000 sponge specimens, this project will provide a phylogenetic context that will improve the understanding of all aspects of sponge biology.

Proper Incorporation of sponges in the Tree of Life is imperative, because there is wide consensus that sponges comprise the primary trunk leading to more complex animals. Data from this project will test this hypothesis and resolve many "branches" within the sponge tree of life. This project will assist communication and collaboration within the international sponge research community by creating an internet-accessible database. This project will provide numerous outreach and educational opportunities, including undergraduate and graduate student training, intensive field courses, professional workshops, and conference symposia. This project benefits society as a whole by helping to track the origin and distribution of crucial genes (and chemical markers) that are useful in medicine and industry and by establishing new model systems for the study of early animal evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the Porifera Tree of Life (PorToL) project was to support collaborative research to evaluate the taxonomy, systematics, and evolutionary history of sponges (phylum Porifera). Sponges are currently classified into 4 classes, 25 orders, 128 families, and 680 genera, with over 8,500 described species. We sought to construct a definitive phylogeny for Porifera using a variety of molecular and morphological approaches to systematics. We also sought to support graduate student research on Porifera and to develop an international team of collaborators working on various aspects of sponge biology.

 

As part of this collaborative project our group was responsible for sequencing complete mitochondrial genomes of sponges and for using mitochondrial genomic data for reconstructing phylogenetic relationships among the major lineages of Demospongiae and Hexactinellida. We participated in two field expeditions to collect sponge specimens from the Bocas del Toro Archipelago (Panama; hosted by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute). In addition, we obtained and analyzed specimens from permanent collections at the Smithsonian Institution (National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C.) and the Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institute (Florida Atlantic University, Florida). We also formed international collaborations with groups at the Station Marine d'Endoume (Marseille, France), Limnological Institute (Irkutsk, Russia), Sars International Centre for Marine Molecular Biology (Bergen, Norway), and the National Museums Northern Ireland (Northern Ireland, UK). Our group has participated in three taxonomic workshops sponsored by the PorTol project for sponge experts from multiple universities and museums around the world. These workshops facilitated collaboration and cooperation among a diverse group of taxonomists at multiple stages of career development.

 

More than one hundred complete and many partial mitochondrial sequences were determined as part of this research. A total of 20 publications have resulted from this project, with at least 2 additional publications in preparation. Our research contributed to the ongoing revision of sponge taxonomy by providing data for:

a) recognition of Homoscleromorpha, the forth class of sponges, previously considered to be a part of Demospongiae;

b) re-establishment of two major families in Homoscleromorpha;

c) recognition of four subclasses of the class Demospongiae: Myxospongiae, Keratosa, Haploscleromorpha, and Heteroscleromorpha;

d) recognition of paraphyletic nature of haplosclerid sponges;

e) elucidation of phylogenetic position of freshwater sponges;

In addition, our work contributed to the description of several new species of sponges.

 

Our work has also transformed our understanding of animal mitochondrial genome organization and evolution. We have shown that animal mitochondrial genomes are much more diverse then previously thought and demonstrated many features unusual for animal mtDNA, including multipartite and/or linear genome organization, mRNA and tRNA editing, translational frameshifting, fragmented rRNA genes, presence of introns, among others.

 

4 graduate students and 17 undergraduate students have been trained and supported by this project and its REU supplement. Two of the graduate students received additional training in sponge systematics by participating in the project-sponsored course on the "Taxonomy, Systematics, and Ecology of Caribbean Sponges" at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute's Bocas del Toro Research Station.
